newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile, Peru hit by quake measuring up to 6.2.
newsitem.headline: Chile, Peru hit by quake measuring up to 6.2.

text.p: An earthquake measuring up to 6.2 on the Richter scale hit northern Chile and southern Peru on Tuesday, causing landslides and startling residents but there were no reported injuries, officials said.
"People were frightened and telephone service was interrupted but we have not received any reports of any damage," said Emilio Lorca, head of the seismology department at the Universidad de Chile.
Local radio also reported that the tremor had caused brief power cuts in several towns.
The tremor, which struck at 2:33 p.m. local time (1833 GMT), measured 6.2 and had its epicentre in the Atacama Desert east of the port of Arica, Lorca told Reuters.
An official at the Geophysical Institute of Peru said the quake and two aftershocks ranged in magnitude from 4.6 to five on the Richter scale.

The first quake was centred in the Pacific Ocean 20 miles (30 kms) southwest of Tacna, and the epicentre of the second, measuring 4.6 on the Richter scale, was 6 miles (10 kms) east of the city, he said. Tacna is about 840 miles (1,350 kms) south of Lima.
Valentin Quinones, a Peruvian civil defence official in Tacna, said the city suffered no major damage.
Peruvian radio dispatches said there were no immediate reports of injuries in the region.
The area is near two mines owned by U.S.-based Southern Peru Copper Corp., Peru's largest copper producer, where floods interrupted production early this year.

Southern officials said they were unsure if its operations in the region, including the Cuajone and Toquepala open-pit copper mines, had been affected. They said they had not received reports of damage or assessed the situation.
